intro: Gastrolobium vestitum, commonly known as the hairy wattle, is a perennial shrub native to Western Australia. It is characterized by its yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer, and its distinctive hairy foliage. The plant thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal and inland regions. It is part of the Fabaceae family, which includes many legumes, and it has the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil. Due to its ornamental value and hardy nature, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
